133.content:
Malon awoke early like she does every morning. The ranch was quite and noisy as all ways after doing all her chores she went to check the mail as she does every morning.

Looking at mail she saw a letter addressed to her. I said "Would you like to presue a carrer in magic study research we'll pay 500 rupees a week to cast a mandatory spell that shouldn't affect your daily life."

She was intrigued at the letter although she never knew anything about it she was always interested in magic. The note continued "if you agree to terms below check the box marked yes below.

Paying absolutely no attention to the terms she checked the box. Suddenly a blue light engulfed her it felt warm. Soon the light dispersed. Malon examined herself for a second.
133.title: An Odd Offer

1331.content: How is she shrinking exactly?
1331.title: She begins to shrink.

choices: ..suddenly slammed the door shut after Malon went in.
..notices Malon is now as small as a doll.
13311.content:
“Well..?” she rhetorically asked.

She then sighed, and shrugged.
“Yet again a rip off from some unskilled witch or wizard…”

She picked up the usual bucket with which she would milk the cows, although something was strange about it: it felt heavier and yet it was completely empty.

“I guess I should simply workout some more, even though my job does not allow me to laze around much.”

As the young woman was heading to the Lon Lon Ranch’s barn, something bothered her again as she reached for the door knob: her hand, which would naturally get the door open in a split second, this time failed to grab on to the door’s handle, forcing her to take a look at it more carefully.

“Oh silly me, my hand was simply below the-huh?”

The blue aura previously surrounding her flared again from her body. And as it did, the world around her seemed slightly bigger.

“What the…” she stuttered. “Let's blame it on fatigue, okay? I must probably be overworked and feel a little dizzy. A spontaneously growing barn or blue light coming out of nowhere isn't a thing…”

She therefore pushed the door open, although this again required a greater effort from the farmer.

“I must get this door greased apparently…Gee, why is everything going wrong this morning?!”

Once inside, while Malon was facing the cows, the same blue shimmer engulfed her again, but this time she clearly witnessed its aftermath, causing her to drop the bucket as her frustration was building.

“Okay, this stupid mail pranked me with some shrinking spell or something. Now let's see who the culprit is.”

Once back to the mailbox, she glanced at it to find its origin, thankfully mentioned on the message.

“Of course, it's from the Kakariko Village apothecary. I should have known better.”

Taking advantage of Ingo’s absence -he would always sleep more than his employees- she jumped on Epona, which thankfully was still fitting the size of the downsized milkmaid. Malon felt herself shrinking again as she was rushing through Hyrule Field, but the travel proved short enough.

“If I'm lucky, I might manage to yell at them before requiring riding a bee to complain to those Goddesses damned apothicarians!”

After jumping out of Epona, Malon clearly saw how the town’s inhabitants were looking at her. But could she blame them? She was as tall as a ten year old girl, although her puberty-altered body had stayed the same. She slammed the shop’s door open, making her anger obvious. The shop owner, a handsome young man, who would normally always smile to his customers, was this time looking rather anxious.

“Hello, sweetheart, how can I help you?” he said with his sugary voice faking his uneasiness.

“I'm no kid, you hear me?” Malon angrily replied. “I'll have you know I got pranked by a mail from your shop, it contained a spell that turned me like...this!”

The man did not look surprised, although his face turned darker.

“Yes, I guess we can only blame the old hag for this.”

“The old who? Who are you talking about..?”

“About me.” An old woman’s voice said.

Malon was astonished at the sight of the newcomer. She really looked like an old hag!

“Now, come to my laboratory. It might not be too late!” She said before maniacally laughing.

Malon complied, although the ever worried gaze of the salesman was in no way a good omen. Once in the inner part of the apothecary, its owner…
13311.title: A small trap

133111.content:
Malon turned to the old woman -who now was effectively three times her height, and she was not especially tall to begin with!- as the sound of the door slammed.

“What's the haste for?” Malon asked with her now high pitched voice.
“Is it already too late for treatment..?”

The old woman creepily laughed.
“The only thing that you can't do anymore now...is to escape!”

“What do you mean, I just need your help to-hey, put me down!” The shrinking farmer squeaked, as she was now even smaller.

“Worry not. The faster you are shrinking, the faster your size will stabilize.” The shop owner said, holding Malon in her hand, her grisp around the miniature girl’s waist.

“H-how can you know that? Except if you are the one responsible for my situation!” Malon shouted, pointing her tiny finger at the witch looking woman.

“That's not exactly true. But you have a point when you say I've planned your arrival. Now if you excuse me, I have to introduce you to my other...little friends.”
She said, locking the minuscule farmer in a wooden cage.
“Next time you'll think twice before trusting mails promoting magic! My master is going to be very proud of having such a beauty in his merchandise!”

“M-master? So you are abducting and shrinking people,” Malon deducted as she took a look at the other cages around, “for a business of some sort?”

“Why of course! Do you really think I do that out of sheer pleasure? You little people are a pain in the neck to take care of.”

And so the creepy woman left, leaving Malon in her cell, now that she was as tall as a toothpick. Malon fell on her knees, and sighed.
“You bet that salesman guy looked weird, no body would want to work with a creepy old lady like that…”

“You know, it could be worse…” an unknown voice said.

“W-who said that?” Malon asked, snapping out of her pessimism.

She then saw a short boy dressed in green, wearing a hat reminding the shrunken milkmaid of someone, although she could not remember whom exactly.

“The great Mido, at your service.” The tiny boy said.

“Great is a little hyperbolic, if you ask me,” Malon grinned, even though she knew she was not especially tall either.
“How long have you been here anyway? And more importantly, what's going to happen to us?”

“From what I heard, some of us are going to be used as guinea pigs for her new potions-” Mido said.

“-and the others?! What about them?” the redhead woman interrupted him.

“-they’ll get transferred to the old lady’s big cheese…That's all what I know.”

Malon put her hand over her mouth, realizing what that meant. The creepy witch promised to send her to her “master”...What was awaiting her ahead? Trying to change of topic, she asked:
“How did you end up at that size and trapped here anyway?”

Mido shrugged.
“I ordered a potion to turn into the handsome guy the girl I have a crush on would love. But as soon as I took a sip, I collapsed. Next thing I know, I'm a few inches tall and trapped inside that cage…How about you?”

“I received a cursed mail which…dragged me here and slowly shrank me down to that size! Tough luck, huh?”

The door then opened.

“Speaking of bad luck…” Mido commented.

As Malon turned to the door, she saw…
133111.title: ..suddenly slammed the door shut after Malon we...

1331111.content:
The shop owner stepped in, her shade she was casting over the light radiating from the freshly open door hinted about the minuscule prisoners fates. Malon's worries were even more genuine as her abductor’s hand reached for her cage, grabbing the handle on the top of it, and lifted it. Malon was using all her strength to not slip to the other side of her prison and knock herself unconscious, although this would have at least been helpful to prevent her from losing control over the fear invading her, as it was the case just now. Her scream, although at a far more sharper tone than what it should be, at least given her current size, echoed through the old woman’s ear like the most annoying of all noises.

“Oh, won't you shut up already?! Foolish girl. This is a privilege I am granting you here. Furthermore, you are not coming alone…”

A synchronized gasp emanated from all the prisoners, whom Malon had not even paid attention to, given her state.

“...Fear not, you idiots! I have already chosen my secondary VIP,” she said, seizing an empty cage.

“She lost it,” Malon thought. “There's no one in that cage!”

“I'll get you a special friend so that my master is as twice as satisfied!” she fiendishly grinned.

“H-help!” Malon shouted as she was being carried outside the shop.

While they were crossing the streets of Kakariko Village, Malon's cell suddenly turned dark, as the wooden bars separating her from the rest of the gigantic world were covered by a black layer.

“See? I'm not that evil. I always make sure my little passengers have a blanket for the night.”

But Malon was no idiot. She knew very well what the curtain over the cage was for: it would be rather suspicious if the townsfolk was to see one of its merchants transporting a living doll begging to be released across the normally peaceful city.

After they walked past the village -the only way for the shrunken woman to figure it out was to no longer hear normal sized people around her talking-
, Malon could no longer tell where they were going, the black curtain obstructing her sight. How was she going to escape now, since she would have no idea where she had been left? Not to mention her tiny size would definitely make her odd of running away even more difficult. Dozens of minutes had passed since their departure out of Kakariko Village.

“Gee, that old hag’s stamina is no joke!” Malon said out loud.

“You bet it is, sweetheart. Now be a good little girl and keep quiet. We're almost there.”

She had particularly stressed her pronunciation on the word “little”. The miniature Malon sighed, preferring to save her energy in trying to find a way out of that mess, rather than wasting it in replying to her sassy kidnapper. On a second thought, Malon wondered: who could possibly be this “VIP” she was talking about..? The answer did not take long to arrive, as the constant quakes striking the milkmaid’s cage at each of the old hag’s steps brutally ceased.

Outside of the space Malon was trapped in, was a familiar voice echoing.

“I'm truly sorry for bringing you here, at the entrance of Kokiri Forest…” the mysterious man said.

“Oh, don't worry about that.” she waved in a sugary manner.

Malon did not know what to do. If this man was going to be this crackpot’s next victim...it was her duty to warn him at all cost!

“I have the potion you've ordered. You should take a sip of it right now, it is not meant to be left out in the cold for long!” the old woman eagerly said.

As she was looking for a specific bottle among the flasks she had brought along, Malon thought this was the right opportunity to draw the newcomer’s attention. She started to kick the wooden beams as hard as she could to make noise. There was no way she would miss her only chance of saving herself, as well as this man!

“What's that strange box you're carrying anyway?” he asked. “It sounds like there's a rat trying to break free from it!”

“A rat you say?!” Malon shouted, her feet still hitting the cage. But her voice was far too high-pitched for her protestations to be heard.

“Exactly, you must be psychic, my good sir. I understand why you needed this magic enhancing mixture from me!” she said, handing the bottle over.

“Uh oh !” the shrunken farmer girl squeaked, knowing well what was going to happen, given Mido’s fate.

And indeed, hearing the potion pouring away in gulps, followed by a predictable cry of astonishment as the potion took effect. Soon after, as the dark curtain over Malon's cage was lifted, she saw the other cage was occupied by…
1331111.title: ..the old woman again!

13311111.content:
Malon stared at the young man in the green tunic now sharing her fate. His face, and even his way of dressing was...oddly familiar to the farmer. Although the situation was not suited for it, she noticed how she was blushing. She shook her head to focus.

“Come on,” she told herself. “One problem at a time. I should get his attention and try to reassure him. Finding a friend in this situation is the least I can do to make it better.”

She then stealthily reached for his cage, her arm crossing the bars separating her from the new prisoner. Trying to poke him awake, she extended her arm even further, while looking up, at the old woman. The latter was fortunately not even thinking about them, apparently far too satisfied of her recent harvest:

“Yes, with these two...The Ghost Hunter is finally going to accept me as his student! With his magical spells added to my potions, I shall be invincible! Even Ganondorf will fear me!”

As Malon was listening, she blinked as she understood what this was implying. That Ghost Hunter...Whoever he was, was the one responsible for her shrinking! She had to wake that guy up, and find a way for them to escape! Someone with such a spooky name could not be a good omen for the two prisoners.

“Come on! Wake up already!” Malon shouted as she was grabbing and shaking one of his arms.

“Gee...Did I just find someone even lazier than my father?!” The milkmaid moaned.

She then remembered how that kid, Mido, told her how the shrinking potion knocked him unconscious, the only problem was that she had no idea how much time it would take for that man to wake up. She had to find a way while the old hag was distracted: such an opportunity was not going to to show up again! As her mind was cooking up a solution, the old lady’s carelessness kicked in, as she walked through a bunch of bushes, the cages in her hands clashing against the vegetation. Malon instinctively closed her eyes and hunkered down as the leaves and thorns were making their way across the cells. Malon gasped as she felt something dragging her against one of the cage’s walls! Looking at the plants storming inside, she noticed she got stuck against vine: one of its thorns had pierced through her dress and was pulling her as they were advancing. Giving it a good kick, the needle, possibly as big as a javelin to Malon, broke loose while they finally made it out of the miniature jungle. After breaking free from all this mess, the farmer took a look at her unconscious companion. To her surprise, he was left unscathed: the vines and branches passed over him as he was lazily hugging the ground.

“It sometimes seems that laziness DOES solve all problems…” Malon commented.

In spite of her frustration, something caused hope to shine on her face: the long, sharp thorn remained in her cage, letting her pick it up to wield it like a spear.

“If I were to thrust it into this old fossil’s thumb, that'd serve her right!” She thought, although she quickly gave up on this idea. After all, if one was stung by a wasp, how long would it take for it to end up squashed as a retaliation? She therefore shook her head, thinking of a better plan, since her eyes glanced at the keyhole of her cage.

“I...I never picked a lock before, especially at this size…Not to mention if this was to fail, I'd be truly screwed.”

But as she saw them getting closer to the remains of Castle Town, a place known for its bloodthirsty Redeads, Malon did not hesitate any longer.

“By the Goddesses, let it work!” She prayed.

The thorn then stabbed the keyhole and was stirring around its mechanism while Malon was manipulating it.

“Come on, come on, just open already!” She said as her panic was building up, and yet the door was refusing to budge. A sudden shock caused Malon's cage to quake.

“Stupid rock!” Her abductor said while stabilizing herself after tripping on it.

Reassured by the fact that she was still unaware of what the shrunken woman was up to, Malon was even more satisfied as she heard the door unlock, deducing the old woman’s clumsiness weakened the wooden door more, enabling the milkmaid to pick its lock successfully. She was brought back to reality when she remembered that opening the gate was only the easy part: she still had a jump to make to join an unconscious shrunken guy if she truly desired to save him! Taking a long breath, Malon jumped, her improvised weapon pointing forward. Despite the difficulty of the maneuver, she not only succeeded in jumping far enough, but the tip of her lance landed right into the door of the other cage, simply bursting it open.

“Holy cow, that cage certainly is tougher from the inside than from the exterior!” She said rubbing her head, barely recovering from the impact.

She did not waste any time and took the unconscious man on her shoulders: she could thank all her work in Lon Lon Ranch for drastically increasing her strength. Only two things were lacking for her evasion plan to be perfect: finding a way to jump off and not splatter on the ground, and if she could by the way find a way to restore them to normal size, then she could start to truly find some relief.

“Because I'm certainly not in the mood for starting a new life by milking aphids and riding ladybugs in an ant sized farm, like an ideal couple!”

She blushed again as she said this. What was wrong with her? She did not even know who that guy was! Shaking her head, she marvelled at a nearby branch, and grinned as she jumped right onto it, her smile even more obvious as the old lady was still on her way to the ill fated Castle Town.

“I think we can finally take a breath!” She told her companion as she turned to him.

Strangely enough, something caught her attention:
13311111.title: A small and tricky reunion

133111111.content:
Malon’s gaze kept its focus on a strange item attached to the belt of the man she saved. She curiously could not stop to stare at it…It indeed felt oddly familiar to her. Yet again, the young woman blushed.

“There's no time for sitting around! First off, I need to find a safer place…for both of us.” The tiny lady said as she was dragging the poisoned man towards a less exposed spot. She found a bunch of dandelions under which they remained for a dozen of minutes, allowing the minuscule milkmaid to have a break, peacefully lying on the ground.

“Talk about a bad day! Now that the old fossil is no longer a threat, I have to find a way to get us back to normal size…”

She thought about how she had left Lon Lon Ranch before opening this stupid letter. Ingo was probably raging at her absence and already reducing her salary for going missing without any explanation.

“He may think he can shrink my salary small enough to scare me, but it'll never be as tiny as I am right now…”

She shook her head, failing to find a solution to the situation. A faint grunt snapped her out of her despair.

“Huh?” Malon said while taking a look at her protégé.

The latter stirred around, before slowly getting up.

“What the...Where am I..? What...What is this place..?” he said with an obvious confusion.

“Welcome to Hyrule Field,” Malon casually said, sitting on a rock behind him.

The young man turned, surprised by the redhead’s presence.

“H-hi!” She awkwardly waved at him, smiling.

“Hum, hello.” he replied. “Excuse me miss, but what are we doing here..? I don't remember coming to this forest, in fact I sweared I simply was-”

“-buying a potion from an old creepy lady.” Malon concluded.

“Exactly! How did you know?” the blonde haired man asked.

“That's a long story. To answer your first question, we're in the middle of Hyrule Field as I just said, although Castle Town is half a kilometer away, but going there on foot would take us the entire day.”

“Why is that? Hyrule isn't that big of a kingdom.”

“We aren't that tall either…” Malon moaned.

“What do you mean we-WOW!”

The stranger stepped back as a dog-sized snail was passing by their lair.

“Holy cow, did you see that?” he asked, impressed.

“You bet I did...As I told you, we're tiny.” Malon said without much interest, although she also tried to sugarcoat the truth to the newcomer.

“Don't be ridiculous, everyone knows that people don't-”

But Malon’s patience was running short. She had been cursed, captured, and treated like merchandise. Getting mocked by the one she struggled to save was what caused her to lose it.

“I'm telling you we are tiny! Tiny, you hear me?! I've been through hell to get you out of that old hag’s clutch, while she had captured me as well! Know your place, Fairy Boy!” she shouted at him before running across the grass, her frustration overwhelming her.

“What...What did you call me?!” the man shouted back, but Malon was already out of sight.

The latter kept walking, her head staring angrily at the ground.

“When I think I could be taking care of my cows, spend some time with Anju in Kakariko Village...but no, instead I am as tall as a toothpick with that ocarina carrying idiot for company! Talk about a day!” She grunted.

A thought interrupted the young woman in her anger. She had called this guy “Fairy Boy” and his ocarina was definitely ringing a bell, but she could not possibly know him...Or could she?
The more her curiosity was building, the weaker was her rage. After all, she had not even asked him his name! The poor guy had not gotten the time to cope with his poisoning that she was already leaving him at his fate?! What kind of savior was she?! Feeling guilty, she slowly turned, and started to walk back to that guy and apologize. Something however interfered with her intentions: while she was walking away without looking where she was heading to, she had managed to stray!

“Oh my, what have I done..?” Malon said as the seamless tall grass was obstructing her view, just like dense trees would have done in an ordinary forest. This was only the beginning of her problems. As she was hurrying into finding her way, her panic was growing. What if she was truly lost? What if she stayed at this size for the rest of her life..? Would someone even find her? Fate did not show any mercy to her since a rough answer to her question did not take long to find her. In her careless progress, Malon tripped and fell, as something gooey stuck to her boot.

“Ow...What the heck was that..?!” she angrily said, trying to get up.

She failed to do so as the cause of her fall was dragging her in the opposite direction she was heading. The shrunken woman leaned forward to identify what was causing this mess. Malon almost had an heart attack once she spotted the threat: a Skulltula, one of those normally already huge spiders, apparently chose the redhead as its next meal. Malon did not normally fear spiders that much -dealing with them was part of her routine when maintaining Lon Lon Ranch- but her reduced size made it look like a living nightmare. The fiendish, eight legged creature’s eyes blinked as a second stream of silk burst out of its gruesome chericae, slowly wrapping the minuscule milkmaid into the whitish glue. Malon did not want to know what was coming next, although she knew she was bound to end up torn apart by the disgusting arthropod. But while she was desperately waiting to meet with her doom so that this could finally come to an end, something unexpected occurred. A storm of golden flames flared between the Skulltula and its prey, enabling the latter to break free, the cocoon Malon was trapped in burning away as the supernatural fire engulfed it to turn it into ashes, mysteriously sparing the shrunken farmer. The poor spider did not prove this lucky, for the mystical flames redirected themselves towards it, and incinerated the monster in the blink of an eye before finally fading away for good.
Malon simply shook her head, wondering if she had not been suffering from some hallucinations. Her doubts were unfounded when she saw the same young man she saved quickly drawing his hand to help her getting up, saying:
133111111.title: A sticky situation

1331111111.content:
“The name's Link!” The man said, helping the young woman to get out of her silk prison. “What's yours?”

Malon slowly got up, grabbing his hand. He apparently did not seem angry about her previous reaction. But this was no reason to get away with it, the farmer thought.

“M-Malon…What's yours? L-listen Link, I'm truly sorry for what I said earlie-”

The man named Link simply shook his head and replied:
“Nah, it's no big deal. I think we both got...bigger issues to take care of, right?”

His somewhat witty pun hinted Malon he was briefed on the situation. After all, did he not save her from this disgusting oversized spider?

“How did you…Do that? With the fire, I mean.” Malon asked.

Link shrugged, and smiled as an apology.

“You mean that?” he said as small and thin flames were flaring from his fingertips. “That's, huh...What we could call a gift I received from a special friend.” he awkwardly explained.

“This guy really seems to have secrets… And despite this, I'm pretty sure I know him…” Malon thought.

The latter raised her finger, about to ask him something again, but Link covered her mouth with his hand.

“My turn for the questions now. What was that name you gave me earlier anyway? You know that “Fairy Boy” thing? How do you even know I used to have a fairy?”

“So we did meet each other!” Malon said out loud. “I remember it clearly now! There was a boy, seven years ago, who would come to play with me and Epona in Lon Lon Ranch! He had a fairy, was dressed in green, and he even owned an ocarina!”

“I do remember a little girl from there, but she was only…” Link started to explain, before interrupting himself, as if he had come to a brutal conclusion.

“What little girl? Who are you talking about? What does it have to do with anything?” Malon asked with impatience.

Link remained silent, trying to think of a way to explain he had been unconscious for seven years after entering the Temple of Time. He therefore opted for a shortened version of the story.

“You nailed it. That boy, this was me. But since I was...busy for a couple of years, I struggled to recognize you, just as you did with me.”

“But what have you been doing during all those years..? What about that blue fairy who was always flying around you?”
She unknowingly said that with jealousy.

“Well, that's a very long story, literally speaking. When I...went missing, I never found my fairy again.”

“Oh, I'm sorry,” Malon said, although with some hypocrisy.

“I think I know how to save her. That's why I was investigating this strange old woman’s business. But it seems like she was aware of my suspicions and tried to get rid of me by doing…this.”

“That's what I would call tough luck.”

Link shrugged and replied:
“Well, we're in the same boat anyway. And complaining isn't that effective of a solution am I right?” he grinned.

“I guess you are, although I have no idea how we are going to find a cure for our condition.” Malon commented.

“I think one of my special friends could fix this in the blink of an eye, if we can reach one of them, that is.”

“Who are you talking about exactly?” the milkmaid asked.

“Why, the Great Fairies of course.”

“The Great Fairies, you say? Like those magical ladies that live in fountains from bedtime stories?” a skeptical Malon asked.

“Indeed. But if you think that I'm a lier, then sure, enjoy your life as a mere bug. Now if you excuse me, I have work to do.” Link said, taunting her as he walked away.

“H-hey wait a second!” Malon begged him.

“What?” the man asked.

“Okay, I'm sorry, I'll take your ideas seriously. Besides, I don't think you'll say no to a guide to help you making your way across Hyrule, right? A lot of things have changed over those seven years.” The farmer girl said, confidently standing before her companion.

“Of course,” he answered. “And I was certainly not going to leave you behind, especially after your efforts to get me out of that cage. I'm just throwing some jokes to keep you awake!” he said as he winked.

“I would call that a threat, not a joke, you moron!” Malon thought.

But as they were making their way, with Link getting rid of the monsters by scaring them away with his magic and Malon showing him the way across the seemingly tall grass to the shrunken adventurers -she could thank her experience of delivering her products to Kakariko Village for that- they optimistically kept progressing and talking to each other.

“I never asked you but,” Link said, hesitating. “How did you get shrunk anyway?”

Malon awkwardly laughed and told him:
“I've been an idiot. I received a letter containing a curse and I followed its instructions. I then went to Kakariko Village as I was slowly shrinking down, where I got captured by that freak of a woman to eventually witness you ending up in the same mess as I am now…”

“Oh well,” Link said, getting rid of another Skulltula with a burst of Din’s Fire -his sword being far too small to be of any use-, “You can't always do things right.”

As he was saying this, the thunder roared and a thick lightning bolt flared across the sky, tearing it apart in a flash blinding them both.

“I don't know where you want to go to find that special friend of yours, but we should prepare ourselves better if we truly hope to achieve anything.” Malon commented.

“Indeed,” her friend replied, looking at the nearby neaby leaves shielding them from the falling raindrops.

They therefore chose to…
1331111111.title: The grasshopper and the ladybug

choices: "Don't you think you need any more sleep?"
13311111112.content:
In a mutual nod to stop their progression and ensure their long term survival, the two took shelter under a bunch of dandelions, and proceeded to gather nearby resources, such as leaves, flower petals and even small rocks -which were particularly difficult to manipulate given their current situation- to strengthen their lair from any nearby predator, or simply from the soft rain progressively evolving into an airborne maelstrom. Malon was normally not afraid of thunderstorms, but the flashy cracks popping out of the sky seemed like amplified, as if the three Goddesses were unleashing their wrath all together. The spooky dark clouds soiling the usual sunlight by casting their raging shadows did not help either. The young farmer almost regretted the nights she would spend working to compensate for her father's laziness, when the menacing clouds were scaring the cows and Cuccos alike. Shaking her head to focus on what was happening now, she contemplated the walls of stray she had just built, and found some relief in the quality of her work. Even the upcoming storm’s icy winds would not pierce through her minuscule but detailed construction.

Meanwhile, Link was breaking rocks into bricks and sticking them together using the clay he found a few steps away. He then used them to cover the mud of their improvised shack. Drawing his sword, he shredded the petals into something similar to cotton, resulting in comfortable beds. The two also combined their strength to drag a chunk of wood as big as an apple into the camp, providing enough fuel to sustain a fire for the entire night. Both fatigued after such an unexpected and emotionally challenging day, Link and Malon agreed on taking a rest and calling it a day, they roasted some berries they had found, resulting in a delicious jam. They even found the time to build what could roughly be called a bathtub by hardening the clay with Link’s magical flames and collecting pure water from rain drops. Once feeling clean and revived by the water -they obviously took turns to appreciate the pool, they were only friends after all- they finally opted for taking a nap on the smooth beds waiting for them. And although they were very comfortable, they -or Malon at least- struggled to fall asleep. She therefore took a look at her companion, lying next to her, and right before the latter closed his eyes, she asked:

“Say...wouldn't it be safer if I was watching over the camp for the night?”

“Are you saying you're not going to sleep at all? Tomorrow's going to be a long day you know? Not to mention I can take care of it no probl-” Link tried to say, before getting interrupted by this time Malon's own finger shutting his mouth.

“Listen. I'm thankful for everything you've done for me. I'd be dead meat if it weren't for your help with that Skulltula. Now I think it's up to me to prove useful. So be a nice Fairy Boy and get some sleep. I'll take care of the camp for that night.” Malon said with a smooth tone she was not used to.

As Link indeed felt tired, he gave up and nodded, before saying:
“Wake me up in a few hours. It's no use to keep ourselves alive during the night if one of us can't make any progress because of pointless fatigue.”

“Got it.” Malon nodded back.

Link therefore closed his eyes, and a few minutes later, snores were already echoing throughout the shelter. Malon, on the other hand, did not pay attention to it and unconsciously focused on the young man’s face instead. The tiny milkmaid facepalmed as she realized she was starring at him like a pervert instead of watching the surroundings, as she was supposed to do. Thus, Malon sat in front of a square shaped hole they had dug through the wall to serve as a window. While starring at the beauty of the lightning flaring from above, Malon almost found her warm and comfortable new house to be more pleasant than Lon Lon Ranch: at least Ingo was not there to yell constantly at her for not working efficiently enough. Speaking of the Wolfos, he was certainly storming with rage even more violently than the thunderstorm she was witnessing for her mysterious absence. The young woman struggled to understand why she was so reluctant about returning to her former life, and sure, she was eager to grow back to normal size, but was she really willing to get back working for that tyrant of Ingo? Malon had always been a very hard worker, even more than Ingo. And yet, she was far from being treated as she rightfully deserved, although she grew accustomed to it. And so she kept looking at the spectacular sky for hours, meditating on her previous and current situation alike, so that she could find an answer to the dilemma poisoning her mind.

She felt like a jolt when Link touched her shoulder, waking her up.

“You okay?” he asked.

“I want to stay with Link!” Malon brutally shouted at an imaginary interlocutor.

“What do you mean? I'm right here, right now!” Link laughed.

Malon gasped as she understood she had been dozing off against the window instead of making sure they were safe as promised.

“It's not what you're thinking!” she quickly tried to explain. “I was just watching through the window to make sure that-”

“-I wouldn't feel lonely when I'm snoring like a Goron?” Link joked. “It's alright. It was my turn to keep an eye on you anyway.”

“What…What did I say, like, just after you talked to me?”

Link laughed before answering:
“I'm not sure but, I heard you saying you wanted to stay with me. It's up to you to provide me with a translation.”

Malon smiled and shrugged.
“You know, I don't think dreams are very relevant of what one is truly thinking.”

“Or are they..?” She awkwardly thought, as Link was taking position before the window, letting her find some rest on her bed. Although she was on the brink of starting a brand new dream, she asked, after covering her mouth with her hand while she was snoring:
13311111112.title: A grassy night shift

choices: ...Awkwardly laughed and stepped back from each other.
133111111121.content:
“How about me, you ask?” Link rephrased with confusion.

“Well yeah…What do your dreams tell you? What do you think about them?” Malon insisted.

Link started to walk back and forth inside the small shack they had built.

“I could provide you with a satisfying answer, but…”

“But what?” the curious redhead asked.

“You might think it's pretty crazy stuff.” Link said, now scratching the back of his head.

Malon smirked at his comment.
“Come now, Fairy Boy, should I remind you we are as small as bugs, we're currently spending the night under a bunch of flowers we are using as a roof for a house we built that looks more like an ant hill than anything else? You can't get any crazier than that.”

Link smirked back, and proceeded to explain.

“Alright, alright. Basically, seven years ago, I once had a dream in which I was in front of Castle Town, when a thunderstorm was starting to rage...Just like now, as I'm thinking about it. Anyway, what I saw that night, was Princess Zelda and her bodyguard escaping from the city, while Ganondorf was chasing them!”

Malon, impressed, could not help but ask: “That's a frightening nightmare to say the least, but where are you going exactly with this?”

Link looked very embarrassed now, especially as he was blushing and nervously biting his tongue.

“Well my point is simple: everything I saw that night truly happene-”

Malon unfortunately had to show a little more patience on Link's tale, since the latter had clumsily tripped into the four centimeter wide pool (which in itself was rather spacious to them), forcing him to slowly get out of the water.

“Oh,” Malon teased him. “Don't bother getting out of there. After all, there's nothing like fresh water to wake up airheads, right? Especially a cute one like yours.” she mockingly smiled.
“So? What were you saying again?” she asked, before suffering from Link’s retaliation, which manifested as a sprout of icy cold water to her face.

“B-Boys…” She grunted as she was shivering.

“Come on...” Link answered to the grumpy face glaring at him.
“Everyone knows there's nothing like a surprise shower to cheer up sleep deprived sermoning girls!” he openly taunted her.

Malon, keeping her eyes closed, slowly got up, squeezed the water out of her long red hair, before doing something Link did not expect at all: she took off the rest of her clothes -bra and panties excepted - and jumped right into the bathing pool, resulting in an impressive splash, the resulting wave hitting both the nearby walls and Link’s face, and even partially the fire roaring in agony at the center of the shack. As Link rubbed his eyes to clear his blurry sight, what he saw left him somewhat confused: Malon was standing right before Link, asking him:

“I think that should do it for your sermon, Fairy Boy.”

Her assertion was followed by an unexpected silence. Malon brutally thought: “What the hell did I just do?! I'm standing in a pool almost naked with someone I met back a few hours ago! What is wrong with me?!”

But if her mind struggled to find a rational explanation, her heart did the job with remarkable effectiveness. She felt the latter beating harder than ever before and her overall sanity was slipping away as her gaze was meeting Link’s, which looked as confused as hers Malon eventually took a sit in the pool, and tried to focus by asking Link the following question:
“So...What were you saying, I mean before, you fell down?”

Link seemed rather astonished by the change of topic, and certainly found it suspicious, but started over his explanation anyway:
“Long story short, everything I saw at this moment proved to be true: Ganondorf was there, Princess Zelda…”

As Link was absorbed within his tale, Malon kept thinking about their current situation. She almost slapped herself in the face as she came to this harsh yet simple conclusion: she remembered why she never really forgot who Link was. After all, he was the only one to whom Malon had ever given a nickname, especially since she had never felt any interest in boys and girls alike. And yet, she unconsciously remembered him, in spite of those seven years. Not lingering any longer with her thoughts, she acknowledged she had always been loving him, hence her irrational habit to stare at the young man, or even help him as best as she could, especially as he had gotten trapped in the exact same way as she was. Her companion, still talking, did not even notice how his friend was aimlessly looking at the water.

“-That's basically it…”he concluded. “Forgive me if I have been talking for too long, bu-” he said, before noticing with too much delay that Malon was getting dangerously closer.

“Tell me, Fairy Boy…” She defied him as his face was turning red. “There is one simple thing I need to know...Ever since we met each other…Who was I to you?”

Link’s face was now blazing. He simply could not say a thing. “By the Goddesses,” he thought. “What does she have in mind..? Sure, I kinda had a crush on her as a kid, but times have changed…” This last thought unsettled him even more. What did those seven years mean to him anyway? Malon had changed a lot, and so did he, and her mature body looked more than desirable, he could not deny that. As her lips were about to collide with his, Link simply put his doubts away, and mimicked the red haired woman in her undertaking.
Once the kiss ceased, Malon and Link…
133111111121.title: Micro midnight bath

1331111111212.content:
They flinched and returned to their original position, blushing and embarrassed.

“I'm…so sorry, I don't know what I've just done there…” Malon apologized.

“It's…it's alright. I guess we're both kinda shaken by the circumstances, right?” Link said.

“Y-yeah…” Malon replied, although without sincerity.
“I think we should just get some rest now. Tomorrow is going to be a long day…”

Link nodded without adding anything else to the conversation, and headed to bed, so did Malon and only the awkward silence remained.

It was only at midday that Link woke up. Around him was the mess they started last night, the dying embers of their improvised chimney emitting a faint scarlet glow. Link washed his face by splashing it with the pool of running water crossing the shelter. The noise this triggered proved enough to wake up Malon as well, and the latter’s reaction to the scene they left was very similar to Link’s.

“Wow...Talk about a good night of sleep…” Malon casually said, passing her hand over her forehead, as if recovering after a hangover.

“Yeah, I'm not going to object on that!” Link replied with a friendly grin.

“He doesn't seem angry at me for kissing him last night. Does he even remember I did?” Malon mentally wondered. “There's only one way to check it out for sure!”

Thus, she quickly put her clothes on, while Link was making sure the fire had died off, extinguishing it with water, resulting in a white cloud of dense smoke, which took a while to fade away.

“L-link…” Malon tried to say through the coughs the ashy haze was causing.
“About last night, I wanted to apologize. I should have never kissed you like that. I'm sorry.”

By the way Link was looking at her, the milkmaid almost read disappointment on his face, although she could also blame the smoke for messing up with her eyesight. Link, on the other hand, simply laughed and answered:

“Come now, if I were that upset I would have told you already. I apologize too for putting you in such an awkward situation. I only wish we would-”

But Malon never succeeded in knowing what Link’s desire was, for loud noises and quakes were harassing their ears and disrupting their frail shack’s architecture.

“By the Goddesses…What was that?!” Malon instinctively cursed.

This time, Link’s face turned serious. He swiftly waved her into silence, and stood still to sharpen his hearing. The loud stomping shockwaves were increasing in intensity: someone -or something- was definitely getting closer.
As the mysterious quakes reached a paroxysmal level, the outer mayhem threatening them turned silent, letting the flows of constantly splashing water stabilize. This peaceful moment proved to only be the eye of a greater storm, for the roof of the minuscule lair brutally was lifted, a hideous, wrinkle ridden hand tearing it apart.

“There you are, you stupid little pests!” an unfortunately familiar voice roared with satisfaction.

Link did not give to the situation a second thought and rushed towards his sword, still lying nearby in its sheath. He however did not expect such a fast retaliation from the intruder, since the shrunken man never reached his weapon in due time. The old woman grabbed him as easily as if he were a mere mosquito, which, in terms of mass, was a rather accurate comparison.

Given that the tiny farmer could clearly see that the situation was taking a turn for the worse, she looked around her in panic, but certainly not to escape: she grabbed the first item she could find to use as a weapon: fate was cynical, for the young woman did find what she was looking for, but at a price: her hands clutching a burning stick that miraculously had its flames left unscathed by the water spreading from all sides, Malon focused as hard as one possibly could to resist the club’s terrible heat while blisters were forming on her fingers, and thrust the weapon into the gigantic aggressor's thumb. The aftermath did not take long to manifest itself: Link immediately fell down a little further from the shack. Unfortunately, by the time he would make it back to Malon after crossing through the grassy maze, the latter was going to be on her own to keep the diabolical apothecary at bay.

“You…” The old woman thundered. “You again?!” she barked while getting rid of the thorn stabbing her hand.
“This time you're done!” The old woman threatened, reaching for the shrunken redhead.
Malon struggled to break free, but with no weapon nearby, there was no real hope for her to achieve anything, especially with her injured hands. It took no time for her to end up trapped inside a glass jar the apothecary had brought along.

“Easy now,” she said. “There's no need to try to escape this time: you won't find any lock to pick in there.” She taunted Malon while she was pounding the glass walls with her tiny, sore fists.

“How did you find us anyway?!” Malon shouted.

“Well, let's just say you don't find tiny houses with a nice little smoking chimney everyday!” The potion shop owner taunted her.

If the situation was not that chaotic, Malon would have given herself a good slap. Of course this fire was bound to reveal them. But now was not the time to deal with this. Instead, Malon desperately tried to grab on to the bottle cap, and prayed for her weight to be enough to pull the obstacle within the crystal prison. While she was too busy mocking the pitiful efforts of Malon to break free, the old shop owner never noticed Link in time, who in a flash of mysterious green light, popped out of thin air to land on the bottle, his Megaton Hammer shattering the jar with dazing effectiveness. The apothecary growled again while Malon fell on a bunch of leaves, softening her landing. Link on the other hand, hit the ground rather hard, leaving him stunned. Mad with anger for getting fooled over and over by the shrunken fugitives, the giantess forgot about Malon to give Link an icy stare.
Without any form of warning, she simply kicked him into oblivion.

“Serves you right, you insect!”

“L-LINK!” Malon cried out of despair.

Defeated by what she had just witnessed, the tiny woman did not even try fight back once in the clutches of the apothecary. And so…
1331111111212.title: Big threat, small skirmish

choices: "Now, let's see how you are going to react to this treatment."
13311111112121.content:
Link was coughing as the water he had swallowed partially made its way up to his lungs. Once feeling better, he walked a little away from the shore and collapsed. He barely survived the kick he received from that old hag, and that was yet again only thanks to the few magical spells he knew: without Nayru’s love, he never would have ended up into the Zora river in one piece. Unfortunately, although the spell was effective at protecting against physical aggressions, it did not grant the ability to breath underwater, that task was up to his Zora tunic. The problem was, that putting it on while in mid air was obviously no easy task, leaving the minuscule young man only his mere muscles to make it out of the monstrous river alive. Exhausted and his willpower failing him after the way the situation had turned, Link let himself fall on the ground, paralyzed with frustration. He failed to save her, whereas she saved him. After spending ten minutes at insulting himself for his incompetence, he shook his head.

“Now, now...Let's try to be useful instead of wasting time. I gotta find her. Let's see...Where could that fiendish woman have taken Malon..?”

As he was rubbing his chin to think of a plan, he was interrupted by a loud shriek that was a little too familiar.

“Can't I get a moment of peace already?!” he asked as he turned to face the threat.

The intruder in question, a Keese, did not hear it that way. Little did it know its prey was more dangerous than it looked. The bat-like creature charged at Link, its fangs ready to bite the delicious little green snack. The monster’s intention was only met with a brutal disappointment since the only food it received was a miniature bomb thrown right into its mouth. Suddenly panicking, the Keese squeaked erratically, before eventually getting knocked down by the fiery blast bursting out of its mouth. Stunned but far from dead -Link’s bomb was after all smaller than a firecracker-, the shrunken man stepped on the monster’s back, still catching its breath.
As Link was about to put it out of its misery, an idea popped out of his mind: if he wanted to find Malon back, he was going to need a vehicle, and using Epona was not option, neither was teleporting with his ocarina or Farore’s Wind: the aftermath of such a strategy at his size was too unpredictable: he might succeed in getting rid of a small Skulltula or a Keese, but dealing with anything bigger would be synonym of death sentence. He therefore needed a swift and stealthy mean of transport. And the solution to this problem was right under his boot.

“Say pal…” he told the bat, his sword’s tip dangerously poking the monster’s throat. “If you could give me a ride around Hyrule…I could be somewhat forgiving and not hold any grudge against you for attacking me. What do you say?”

The Keese nervously nodded.

“Good. See, it doesn't take much to take a smart decision.”

That said, he gave a faint kick on his ride for it to soar and wander across Hyrule Field in search of Malon.


***

The young woman was shaking in fear as she was being brought to a dark room in one of Castle Town’s old buildings. Catching her breath on the wooden table she was thrown on, something interrupted her before she could even recover properly. Behind the faint light the few candles and the spooky Poes provided, the latters grinning at her in the magical cages restraining them, was a silhouette sitting on a filthy crate, its cadaveric hand clutching a stick it was waving at the captured ghosts, causing them to shiver as well, before noticing the loot its grunt had brought.

“Careful,” he said -the voice, although ghostly, definitely sounded male-, “You're far too inefficient in your abductions to harm our victims more than it is required.” He thundered at the old woman. “Now, what do we have here?”

“Understood, master,” the designated servant said. “The lady here is apparently a friend of the Hero of Time, the one you are looking for.”

“I remember well who my targets are, thank you very much. Why are you wasting my time with this worthless peasant?” he growled, pointing at the shrunken woman. “I have no time for keeping hostages. That was supposed to be your job!”

“Y-yes, Master. I understand, but I did try capturing some of his friends, such as those Kokiri kids from the forest, but-”

“Even with them or after capturing the Hero himself, you failed to return him to me.” The cloaked wraith guessed.

Seeing how her boss’s patience was running short, the old woman explained, stammering:
“B-but Master, please listen. With this girl in your possession, not only you have a good opportunity to lure the Hero here, but also a brand new subject to experiment on!”

Malon was speechless, what did all of this mean? Was that guy the reason why she was cursed, and Link was poisoned..? And she certainly did not want to end up as one of those creeps experiments, getting shrunk was more than enough in itself! She therefore desperately bolted towards the nearest corner she found, only to be caught again by a gigantic hand.

“Leave me alone, you freak!” she told the cloaked creature.

“Hm...What an interesting temper. I can't wait to start working on you…” he smirked. “Granny, if you please?”

“Right away.”

She took the struggling Malon again, and transferred her to her new prison. Determined to not end up locked up again, the tiny farmer kicked around, managing to spill a nearby bottle containing a thick and strange liquid. The contact with the foul substance not only grossed both the abductor and the small lady out, but scalded their respective skins as well.

“You stupid bug!” The old hag shouted.
“Look at what you've just done!”

Malon would have been satisfied of herself if she was not suffering this much.

The wizard, in the background, sighed as the old woman painfully put Malon inside the cage.

“You really are taking pleasure at disappointing me…” The wraith like creature commented. “You wish to acquire my knowledge to improve your own magic, and yet you manage to waste my precious fairy elixir?” he asked in a threatening tone.

“N-no…Master...If I may…”

Malon, from her cage, could clearly read terror on the apothecary’s face, something she would be enjoying as well if she was not just as terrified, not to mention the effects of that so called “elixir” on her body.

“What's going to happen to me?” she wondered with fear.

“Enough,” the demon thundered. “Not only this mixture was meant to be drunk, not spilled, but you succeeded in contaminating our subject, making all your efforts vain. And you know what happens when I face such failure…”

“M-MASTER! GIVE ME ANOTHER CHANCE!”

But it was already too late. The imp’s fingers snapped, and the old woman disappeared in a blast of ghostly flames, her cries of despair echoing as if to mark her demise. Malon then saw her new enemy turning to her and saying:
13311111112121.title: The prisoner and the fugitive

choices: ...nothing happens, for his ocarina is too small to be heard.
133111111121211.content:
“Yes…” the cloaked figure murmured. “I have to stabilize your condition immediately. I don't want to have all this time wasted because of a dead subject or one that is too disfigured to be of any use…”

The sinister tone he used dreaded Malon to the soul. She might have grown partially used to her pain, but if what her prison warden was saying was true, then she still had a lot to worry about.

The skulking creature was stirring the different vessels on the series of shelves on the dark and cold stone wall with its staff, as if eager to find something in particular. When he did, the miniature woman could almost spot an expression of satisfaction on her captor’s face, if darkness did not concealed it, that is, although she was rather thankful for that fact: given the way he was grabbing her with his decomposing hand, his face was certainly the last thing she wanted to look at. Malon was far past the typical impression of disgust she would be subjected to when in the hands of someone meaning obvious harm to her. The young woman even held a sigh, as her despair was far beyond what anyone could handle. But it is in that same feeling of hopelessness she found the willpower to fight back: after all what could a shrunken and visibly poisoned person like her lose at this point..? Thus, she interrupted her incarcerator in his manipulation of various chemicals he was stirring together in a small smoking cauldron.

“Say… What do you even have to gain in doing this?” She asked, still trapped in his firm hand. “I seriously hope you're not expecting me to believe you are interested in taking care of me or something? Because I'd rather be left in the middle of Hyrule Field like I was before so that a monster can put me out of my misery.”

Her abductor did not react, and her last assertion truly pained her, for Link remained as an intrusive image in her mind. This guy had gotten involved in this out of pure accident, and certainly was dead as she was speaking. But now was not the time to mourn: she would have plenty of time to do so once in the other world.
Before she could even exploit her despair to yet again taunt her foe, Malon felt something thick, yet refreshing, flowing all over her body. She realized the wraith had just poured the mixture it was preparing on her. Although this should have been a disgusting experience, the rough texture and dark color of the potion were betrayed by the ethereal weight of the liquid, and especially the faint light it was emitting as Malon’s pain and scalded skin were healing away. The next thing she felt, was her very consciousness slipping away as she peacefully fainted under the influence of the concoction, as it magically wore off, revealing wings on the young woman’s back as well as a glowing aura radiating from her body.

“It seems my business is finally going to flourish now…” the mouth under the cloak said in a smirk. “Lord Ganondorf is going to make of me his most powerful assistant once his request for a brewery expert complete! If I can get him the Hero of Time captured as well…then even I won't be able to imagine how great my reward is going to be..!”

And so the Ghost Hunter maniacally laughed, its ghastly voice spooking the specters it previously captured into shivering inside their prison.

***

Link’s right foot was growing sore from beating the Keese into the right direction. His dominant one was clutching his ride tight, for they were heading to Castle Town, this ill-fated place being one of the favorite lairs for creepy people such as the old lady that shrank Link, therefore making of it an adequate starting location for an investigation to find Malon back. But Link was no fool: even with the tamed bat transporting him, he knew he was far from safe. That was why he had been thinking of a strategy: if the latter was to pay off, it would even kill two birds with one stone. Link was flying above the naively wandering Redeads, unable to spot the minuscule prey violating their territory. The Keese was getting progressively nervous as they were getting closer to Ganondorf’s castle. Thankfully for the dim witted creature, paying a visit to the infamous tyrant was not part of his plan. Instead, Link remembered the presence of a Great Fairy within the caves surrounding the remains of the Royal Castle: Great Fairies were the magical wardens of the Hylian Lands, coming to the rescue of poor souls with their powerful healing powers. Not only that, but those immortal beings were also gifted with knowledge they would share with those worthy of it. This way, Link would put an end to this size problem, and, with a bit of luck, acquire the information he required to rescue Malon too. The young man was crossing his fingers for the spirit to survive Ganondorf’s evil influence after those long seven years. His forehead was starting to bead with anxious sweat, since the entrance of the Fairy’s cave was obstructed with a majestic argent boulder -one which even a normal sized person would never succeed in removing- Link only hoped he could squeeze his way through, and that was not going to be an easy task, especially with a Keese only waiting for the moment its fangs could finally slice through his flesh. Once near the entrance, the bat received the order to dive across the thin gap separating the cave from the exterior, causing it to squeak out of fear as it was performing the suicidal maneuver. Luckily, its pilot swiftly used his own weight to stabilize the flight and reach the wall’s breach with unrivaled accuracy. The landing however, was abrupt to say the least. The poor winged animal collapsed out of exhaustion while Link simply jumped off its back. The latter glanced at his ride and said:
“I won't be long, so don't think up of any dirty trick in my back, you hear?”

The monster weakly nodded, apparently far too fatigued for that outcome to be a possibility.

Thus, Link ventured inside the ancient yet magnificent cave: its white stone slabs were intact, and the water flowing from the fountain was crystal clear. Only one important thing was missing. Knowing what he had to do, Link stepped on the golden Triforce carved onto the floor -the shrunken man had to walk up to its inner triangle- and prepared to call the Great Fairy with his ocarina. Once Zelda's Lullaby echoed across the wide sanctuary…
133111111121211.title: "Now, let's see how you are going to re...

1331111111212111.content:
Link put the ocarina back into his pocket and waited, his anxiety still raging.
“Come on, let it work!” he mentally thundered.

A few seconds later -which felt like hours from Link’s perspective- a magical orb of light burst out of the water and progressively grew larger, until taking the form of a gigantic feminine entity, a laughter Link knew all too well echoed throughout the Great Fairy’s lair and concluded the spirit’s apparition. The latter stood in the air, magical bright sparks surrounding her, as she was staring at the golden triangle on the floor, where her rare visitors would stand to consult her. This time however, she was left confused by the absence of her summoner, typically a Royal Family member or one of their loyal servants, and occasionally the Legendary Hero himself, although no one had awaken her in those long seven years. Thus, the spirit awkwardly looked around, trying to determine the source of the call. As it prepared to dive back into the depth of her fountain, something caught her attention: sparks of emerald light were flaring out of the Triforce facing her pool. She therefore took a closer look, as this shimmer was oddly familiar to Farore’s Wind, a spell one of her sisters transmitted to the visitors of her lair. Her doubts proved accurate since the Great Fairy spotted a man dressed in green, carrying a very peculiar sword which made his identity very obvious, the only detail confusing her was the man’s size. She nonetheless greeted the newcomer, acting just like the rest of her siblings:

“Greetings, Hero of Time, I am the Great Fairy guarding this sanctuary. How may I help you?”

Link did his best to sound confident, but the situation did not help. Thus, he answered as followed:
“Well, I required your help to solve a... little problem.”

The spirit laughed and said:
“Why of course, let me get you rid of your fatigue!”

Before Link could object, a warm shimmer enveloped him, effectively revitalizing him, although his size was still the same.

“Th-thank you, but…” Link stuttered, trying to ask her how could she omit a problem as obvious as this one.
“I don't think this fixed the issue I'm dealing with right now.”

And so he explained what happened in details. Great Fairies might be rich in terms of knowledge, but their lack of thorough analysis could make of them very dim-witted interlocutors at times, although Link wisely chose to not mention this aspect.

“This is indeed powerful magic you are dealing with here.” The Fairy commented. “To be honest, even a specialist in magic may find it difficult to reverse its effects.”

“Neat…” Link thought. “I'm sure Malon is going to enjoy hearing that: “Link, I can't believe you rescued me! What? You say that we're bound to stay at this size? That's so great! I always wanted to live in the grass in a shack of mud like a bug! Thank you very much!””

As Link was almost turning back, defeated, the Great Fairy said:
“...that is, if you hadn't come to me!” she smirked.

“You can't be serious…And don't tell me those seven years have gotten you a sense of humor…” Link mentally groaned.

The magical entity snapped its fingers, and a small bottle containing a pinkish substance popped out of thin air, slowly levitating towards Link. He caught the potion, which was of a respectable size for him.

“Given your state, you should barely require one sip of it, not only to grow back to normal, but also to develop a temporary immunity to any magical spells. Be careful though, for it took me years to produce such a quantity of this elixir. Use it wisely.”

“T-Thanks…” Link said, looking at the shining vial with a new interest.

“For what's about your friend, I suggest you simply investigate the inner part of Castle Town. There are a lot of Ganondorf’s servants living in here, where no one is going to disturb their activities. Yet again, I'd be careful if I were you. Good luck!”

And so, she disappeared into her fountain, leaving it up to Link to solve his problems.

“Well…” Link said, taking a look at the mysterious bottle. “If I get it right...I might even be able to cure Malon and even more people with that thing! Now the question is, where Malon is exactly..?”

Thus, he got back to the entrance, restrained the Keese -which obviously proved stupid enough to try to make of the shrunken Hylian its dinner-, Link carefully attached the potion to his belt, preferring to not grow back right away, and mounted on the bat’s back to find where the farmgirl could possibly be. As he was soaring the dark cloud ridden sky, something caught his attention. The normally dark and gloomy ruins of the former city were always pitch black, although an abnormal shimmer was glowing from a peculiar building, which happened to be on fire, hinting Link about the possibility of finally finding who he was looking for.

“I hope she was not in this fire when it started though.” he said, before kicking the Keese to double its speed, oblivious to the ominous nature of his own words.
1331111111212111.title: A call for help.

1332.content:
Malon seemed a little disappointed that the spell did nothing to her. She remembered she had to milk to cows. So she went to the barn and milked them when she was finished she noticed a discarded bottle of milk on the ground.

She picked it up and uncorked it she then sniffed it to check how fresh it was. "Uggh." Malon said squinting as she smelled it. The milk was spoiled is smelled absolutely horrible.

She of course had to dispose of it. While walking toward the exit she tripped over a stray rock on the floor. This caused her to spill the spoiled Milk all over herself. On the covered in foul smelling liquid Malon noticed the room began to spin.

This gave her a headache causing her to feel light headed. The room seemed to be growing to her not just the room the cows,horses, and all the tools too.
1332.title: Don't cry over spilled and spoiled milk.

13322.content:
Malon's dizziness started to fade soon regaining her senses a few seconds later she quickly noticed something was wrong. All the entire room looked much bigger animals,tools and all. The distances between the door and where she was standing was much longer.

She felt something heavy in her pocket. Emptying her pockets was much harder than normal. When she finished she pulled out the mail which was inside her pockets. She sorted it out and checked the letter she had gotten earlier.

In small letters that escaped her eye earlier it was written. "DON`T COME IN CONTACT WITH ANY LIQUIDS FOR THE FIRST HOUR AFTER SPELL IS CASTED. FAILURE TO DO SO MAY CAUSE SERIOUS SIDE-EFFECTS."While reading Malon could feel the paper slowly getting heavier as she read. After reading Malon saw the rest of the room had grown some more.

"What in tarnation is going on here? Malon said still puzzled.
13322.title: Strange side-effect.

choices: Try to cross the perilous Hyrule Field.
Check the farm for anything that could help.
133221.content:
Malon now was seeing exactly what was going on. The room wasn't growing she was shrinking. Her first thought was to panic,she began to pace around the room slowly with tears streaming from her eyes.

"This can't be happening I refuse to believe this." Malon continuously screamed still running around. She quickly ran to the door she was too short to reach the handle. She jumped up and grabbed the door handle vigorously trying to turn it.

"Come on you stupid door." she yelled. To her avail the door unlocked and slowly opened before she let go and dropped down to the floor. Walking outside she felt totally pathetic compared to the farm which was humongous to the still dwindling girl.

"I'd better close the door or the animals may escape." Malon said despite her (handicapped) situation. Malon pushed the door despite her small size it wasn't a very difficult task to do. When the doorwas finally close she it was all ready noon. Comparing herself to the rest of the farm she estimated she was around the size of a doll.

"I'm so tiny now how am I ever going to get back to normal?" Malon said sighing. The only good thing about this was that she stopped shrinking. Looking at her options she only had to choices of hat she could do.
133221.title: Miniature Malon

1332211.content:
Malon knew the only way to get help was to cross the vast Hyrule Field but at her current size it was much more vast. Also the Field was dangerous with all the monsters running about. All those thoughts raced through her mind as she mentally prepared her journey.

She left the farm running across the field. Since there was a dirt path mostly connecting the ranch and the market. She saw no sign of any monsters or people on her way to the market. She was about half way there when she saw a horse driven carteading toward the castle.

"Maybe I can catch a ride on that cart." Malon thought as she scanned the slow moving cart. The cart must of belonged to a carpet salesman because the cart was full of rugs. She saw a stray string hanging off the back of the cart. She grabbed the string like it was a rope and started to climb up it.

When she reached the top of the string she sat at the edge of the cart looking back at the view. She was thankful she didn't have to walk all that way. When the cart made a brief stop at the market Malon used the string to lower herself down.
1332211.title: Journey to the Market

choices: The owner thinks Malon is merchandise.
13322111.content:
Malon felt a little intimidated as the cart left. The market was full of giants that could easily damage her with even noticing. The youngest children were at least 20 ft tall in comparison to her. She had to find someone who could help her but she didn't want to a total stranger to discover her presence.

Malon searched the market hi and low trying to find someone she familiar. She had to watch where she walked people could easily step on her by mistake also the market was known for the wild dogs which was something she didn't want to deal with.

I wasn't long before she stopped to rest next to a booth. She sat on the cork of a bottle that was laying on the ground. The sun was beating down hard. Meanwhile the owner of the booth was taking inventory she searched the ground seeing if there was anything she forget to mark off. There she saw Malon sitting on the bottle on the ground.
13322111.title: Stopped to take a breather.

choices: Try to make a run for it
Stand still and hope they go away
133221111.content:
The owner smiled and reached a hand out. Malon turned around and saw the giant owner reaching for her. She screamed and jumped off, making a run for it. The owner then fainted from seeing a supposedly inanimate object coming to life. She then fell down, huge body crashing down onto the floor.

Malon felt the ground shake, and fell onto her back. She gasped in pain as her ankle got slightly twisted from her awkward fall. Then, she heard a bottle shattering. She looked up and saw that a bottle had fallen out of the owner's pocket. It was full of bugs!

The owner must have been collecting them. But that was no good for Malon. Those bugs were two times the size of her!
133221111.title: Giant Bug Attack

1332211111.content:
She gasped in fright and tried to stand up. She ended up slipping and creating a loud noise, and the bugs looked in her direction.

They instantly began to crawl towards her. Malon backed up until she reached a wall, still grabbing onto her fractured ankle. One of the bugs grabbed onto her legs with its claws and began to drag her in. Malon gave a desperate kick, ending up splitting the bug's head in two. Malon may be a girl, but farm girls are quite strong.

The rest of the bugs were scared away, and scampered off. Malon then found out that the kick managed to twist her ankle back into shape. She stood up and continued out the door. She decided to check out the castle to try to find Link. The Hero of Time might be able to unhex her from this curse.
1332211111.title: Desperate Effort

13322111111.content:
She walked towards the castle. By the entrance there were 2 guards. She stared up fearfully at the 2 titanic figures. They hadn't seen her.
"I don't think I should trust them", she thought.
She stealthy walked between one guard's legs when suddenly the other one spoke.
"Hey! What is that thing?", he said.
"Where?", said the other.
13322111111.title: Walking with caution

133221111111.content:
The guard looked between his legs and saw Malon.
"What is this?", he said, as he bent down, reaching for her. She ran as fast as she could but tripped and fell down. The guard grabed her leg with his thumb and index and lifted her to eye level.
"What are you? Some sort of wingless fairy?", he asked.
"Let me go, you huge brute!", she said.
"Wow, the little one's got her temperament!", he said, chuckling.
"Hey, this is no fun!", she said, "Let me go, now!".
What does he do?
133221111111.title: Caught

choices: Another guard preparing for his shift.
1332211111111.content:
"I think I'll keep her with me." the guard said pulling out a bottle. He stuffed her inside of it and continued his job. Malon felt like she was in a glass prison. She knew she could not escape due to the smooth surface as well as her hurt ankle.

"Let me out of here." Malon yelled up at the guard. He ignored her yelling. Malon furiously began to bang on the sides of the bottle. He clasped the bottle in his hand and began to shake it vigorously. Malon was tossed all around hitting the sides of the bottle repeatedly.

"Please stop this and let me go." Malon asked politely. The guard just stood there ignoring everything. Malon sighed as she watched the scenery from inside the bottle. From a distance she could see someone else approaching the castle gates. But who was it?
1332211111111.title: Bottled Up

choices: Zelda was heading for her room.
Zelda was heading for Link's house.
13322111111111.content:
It was Hyrule's own Princess Zelda approaching the gates of her own castle. The guards (and Malon) watched as she slowly as the young princess grew near.

"Good afternoon Princess!" One of the guards said politely.

"Good afternoon." Zelda replied back. Zelda noticed the guard was holding something. I seemed to be a fairy in a bottle which was not uncommon in Hyrule. However the creature inside was very strange looking.

"What is that you’re holding?" Zelda said curious about the creature inside. The guard took a few steps forward and held out the bottle Malon was trapped in. From inside the bottle Malon could see the gargantuan face of Princess Zelda staring at her.

"This? I found this wingless-fairy thing wandering around on the ground. Do you wish to take it with you princess?" The guard said looking at Zelda's bewilderment. Zelda nodded, and the guard handed the bottle to Zelda.

"Aren't you the cutest thing?" Zelda said as she walked away from the guards. Malon was just handed from one captor to another. Unable to do anything but sit and wait inside the bottle, she hoped the Zelda would help her return to normal size or at lest set her free from her glass prison.

Speaking of Zelda where was she headed?
13322111111111.title: In Zelda's possession.

choices: The key unlocks and somone else enters the room.
133221111111111.content:
Zelda causally strolled thought the castle halls. She was still holding the bottle with the shrunken Malon inside. Malon watched as Zelda opened the door to her room and closed it shut behind her. Zelda sat down at her desk and carefully emptying Malon's into her palms.

"Are you alright little fairy?" Zelda spoke in a soft voice. Malon was silent she, had wasn't so sure Zelda was the right person to help her. However she still replied back.

"I'm not a fairy Pr-Princess." she said obviously unable to talk without stuttering due to her nervousness. Almost completely ignoring her words, Zelda placed Malon on the desk and stood up and walked toward the door.

"When I get back we can have a little fun." Zelda said putting emphasis on the word "fun". After a quick glance she exited the room, closed the door and locked it form the outside.

Malon ran to the edge of the desk and looked over the side. It was too far a jump for her to make. There was no other way down so she waited hoping that someone would return, and by some she hoped it was anyone but Zelda.
133221111111111.title: In Zelda's room

133221111111112.content:
Zelda hailed her personal carrage and climed aboared. Although Link or even Malon at normal size could easely walk but Zelda being a princess she wasnt quite in top physical condition. " Ppp please prencess help me." Zelda simply started playing with her she grabed her foot and held her upside down Malon shrieked in terror and flailed untell she sliped out of her boot and fell the seat below.

Malon got up with anger in her eyes " Give me my boot back now!" Malon yelled up at her captor hoping to knok some sense into her. Zelda naroed her eyes at Malon. "Did you just raise your voice at me?!" she grabed Malons shirt with her fingers and lifted her to her giant face " I think its time you learn your place, at my feet." She then lowerd the tiny girl to the floor at her feet. Zelda stood to her full hight Malon looked up in aw as she towerd over her. Zelda tapped her foot then poked Malon causing her to stumble and fall on her back each and rose her foot over her she started to cry and started begging, Zelda then bendt down and cought her in the boddle. When the arived at Links house Zelda handed Malon in her glass prison "Malon?" Zelda llooked at him in confusion Malon leaped to her feet "Link its me please help me!" Will he help her?
133221111111112.title: Zelda was heading for Link's house.

She gasped in fright but she held her breath. Unfortunately, they caught her scent. The bug licked its lips, moving in towards the delicious looking girl.
